newsitem.title: SIERRA LEONE: Civilians flee fresh fighting in Sierra Leone.
newsitem.headline: Civilians flee fresh fighting in Sierra Leone.

text.p: Frightened civilians have fled a fresh outbreak of fighting between Nigerian troops and soldiers loyal to Sierra Leone's military rulers near the capital Freetown, witnesses said on Sunday.
The cause of the clash at Djui, which began late on Saturday 15 miles (20 km) south east of the city and near Hastings airport, was not clear.
Residents said crossfire between Nigerian troops and the newly constituted People's Army -- soldiers who backed a May 25 coup and rebel allies -- had killed at least eight civilians.

Sierra Leonean military officials said shooting continued on Sunday. They accused Nigerian troops at a nearby base of starting the clash and said soldiers and civilians had been hospitalised in Waterloo to the southeast.
Nigerian commanders were unavailable for immediate comment.

The two sides clashed last Wednesday at Lungi airport across an estuary from the capital as members of the People's Army hunted for a clandestine radio station that has broadcast messages from ousted president Ahmad Tejan Kabbah.
Nigeria, which had troops in the country under a defence pact before the coup, has since reinforced as part of efforts to persuade the military junta to restore Kabbah to power.
Impoverished Sierra Leone's West African neighbours have agreed to try dialogue and economic sanctions as methods of persuasion but have retained the military option.
Kabbah came to power in 1996 after multi-party elections ended four years of military rule. Rebels, who took up arms in 1991, rallied to the coup -- the third in five years.
